timeline.message:
Implement parquet filtering

Add support for additional simple operators
Use parquet-format v2.7.0
Fix reading decimal from parquet when precision is between 1-9 inclusive and 1-18 inclusive
add parquet namespace
Add parquet file to run unit tests
Successfully added tests
Working with FilterApi
Working version of parquet predicate pushdown
Working version. still need to prune INT96 and FIXED_LEN_BYTE_ARRAY
Add unit tests for column projection
Add SupportedParquetPrimitiveTypePruner
Always set a read schema

add parquet namespace

Working with FilterApi

Move SupportedParquetPrimitiveTypePruner to the correct path
Cast tm to PDT to get the same result on all timezones
Cast tm to PDT to get the same result on all timezones
Remove boolean tests because of issues in c client
Run GCS in parallel for perf tests and run parquet tests
concurrency needs to be defined earlier in the script
Get file reader for split we are accessing
Create special configuration for reading parquet from S3

timeline.bodyText: Can we call this something else? I am thinking columnProjectedSchema.
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: I'd prefer to keep it as readSchema because it's the schema we are reading. If there's no projection, it will be end up being all the columns of the Greenplum schema. I realize that the comment might not be accurate though. What do you think?
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: this is a nice improvement in the accessor logic .
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: definitely, the new Parquet APIs help!
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: It might be time to start thinking about how to make this logging more generic. I have something similar in the Avro code.
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: yeah, I've been thinking about this. This definitely helps debug things when you have a large greenplum cluster with concurrent queries. We definitely need better instrumentation to trace the source of the error.
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: why do we need the if?
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: are we worried that those get*() will be called?
replies.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: I assume that getRecordCount() and getRowGroups() might be expensive calls, so I prefer to avoid calling them at debug level, when debugging is not on
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: How do we know all the nodes have been visited?
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: We rely on TreeTraverser to be correct. TreeTraverser has a set of unit tests that should give us some degree of guarantee that we'll visit all the nodes. In theory, there shouldn't be a situation where the queue is not empty after visiting all nodes
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: :) generics. This was a refactoring I did because the code was a bit messy when Alex and I reviewed it. Basically, this will give you the predicate for the given operator
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: We add support for date and decimal types?
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: so date is serialized as an integer by hive, and this supports reading from parquet file generated by hive.
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.author: oliverralbertini

timeline.bodyText: this seems like a lot of work to get the type for a node. Is it possible that this could be cached on the node itself?
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: Well, the node is agnostic to parquet types. These nodes are the result of the expression tree that we obtain from greenplum. We look up the types by name in a hashmap. I think hashmaps should be fast enough for this operation
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.author: oliverralbertini
oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: some of the tests in this namespace share the same schema for test ParquetBaseTest. To avoid code duplication, I created a base class where all the other classes that need the schema inherit.
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: oh my gosh an extra comma
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

replies.bodyText: how do you even see this!
replies.author: frankgh

timeline.bodyText: I like this way of testing. Can we make an alias for COL1 called ALL? helper() could then be named assertRowsReturned(). This line would then read something like assertRowsReturned(ALL) which would be easier to understand than helper(COL1).
timeline.author: oliverralbertini

timeline.bodyText: In this case you might rename helper to filterBuilderFromFilterString()
timeline.author: oliverralbertini
